Company: Chartered Mercantile Bank of India, London and China
Description: Sir Boshan Wei Yuk was a prominent Hong Kong businessman. He served as the head compradore of Chartered Mercantile Bank of India, London and China, and a member of the Legislative Council. He played a key role in public services, including chairing Tung Wah Hospital and co-founding the Po Leung Kuk.

Francisco Yat-Tse, born in Hong Kong in 1854, was the first Comparadore of Banco Ultramarino of Macao. Known as "Chico" by the local Portuguese community, he is believed to be the namesake of Chico Terrace.

Company: Peninsular and Oriental Steam Navigation Company
Description: Kwok A-cheong, a prominent Hong Kong businessman, served as the comprador for the P&O Steamship Company and established the successful merchant house, Fat Hing Hong, in Sheung Wan.

Sir Robert Hotung was a Hong Kong businessman and philanthropist. He was Head Compradore at Jardines and was a director of Hong Kong Land and a board member of Tung Wah Hospital. By the age of 35, he was believed to be the richest man in Hong Kong.

Sir Shouson Chow was a prominent Hong Kong businessman. He co-founded the Bank of East Asia and held various important positions in the government, including the Sanitary Board, the precursor of the Urban Council, and Legislative Council. He was the first Chinese member of the Executive Council.

Sir Shouson Chow was a prominent Hong Kong businessman. He co-founded the Bank of East Asia and held various important positions in the government, including the Sanitary Board, the precursor of the Urban Council, and Legislative Council. He was the first Chinese member of the Executive Council.

Sir Shouson Chow was a prominent Hong Kong businessman. He co-founded the Bank of East Asia and held various important positions in the government, including the Sanitary Board, the precursor of the Urban Council, and Legislative Council. He was the first Chinese member of the Executive Council.

Company: Commercial Bank of India | Hughesdon Calder & Co.
Description: Henry Rutter was a British exchange broker snd financial writer. He was an agent at Commercial Bank of India and a partner at Hughesdon Calder & Co.. He made many publications on financial topics, including ‘Exchange Tables and Arbitrations of Exchanges between England, India, and China’.

Sir Hormusjee Naorojee Mody, an influential Indian Parsi businessman, co-founded the University of Hong Kong and played a pivotal role in developing Kowloon through his successful real estate brokerage, Chater and Mody, with Sir Catchick Paul Chater. His philanthropy extended to founding institutions like the Hong Kong Jockey Club and Kowloon Cricket Club.

Sir Hormusjee Naorojee Mody, an influential Indian Parsi businessman, co-founded the University of Hong Kong and played a pivotal role in developing Kowloon through his successful real estate brokerage, Chater and Mody, with Sir Catchick Paul Chater. His philanthropy extended to founding institutions like the Hong Kong Jockey Club and Kowloon Cricket Club.

Sir Hormusjee Naorojee Mody, an influential Indian Parsi businessman, co-founded the University of Hong Kong and played a pivotal role in developing Kowloon through his successful real estate brokerage, Chater and Mody, with Sir Catchick Paul Chater. His philanthropy extended to founding institutions like the Hong Kong Jockey Club and Kowloon Cricket Club.
Sir Thomas Jackson was the third Chief Manager of HSBC. He had served ten years in the bank and was only 35 years old at the time.

Sir Thomas Sutherland, a Scottish banker and politician, founded HSBC and directed the P&O Company. He was the first chairman of the Hong Kong and Whampoa Dock, and was appointed member of the Legislative Council of Hong Kong from 1865 to 1866.

Charles Montague Ede was a British businessman and unofficial member of the Executive Council and Legislative Council of Hong Kong. He was the general manager of Union Insurance Society of Canton, and was responsible for developing Kowloon Tong.

Company: National Bank of China | Shewan, Tomes & Co.
Description: Anthony Babington was a British merchant and businessman. He was a manager of National Bank of China's branch in Yokohama. He later became the director of Shewan, Tomes & Co. in Hong Kong, a company which contributed the to the foundation of the China Light and Power Company.
Named after HSBC and Bank of China nearby.
Named after International Finance Centre nearby.
The area was named after a merchant named Leighton (Leighton & Co.), who had constructed a godown nearby. In 1853, a police station was built on the same site.
The area was named after a merchant named Leighton (Leighton & Co.), who had constructed a godown nearby. In 1853, a police station was built on the same site.

George Fenwick was a British enginner and was the owner of shipyard located at Queen’s Road East and Ship Street in Wanchai. By 1884, Fenwick established Fenwick & Co, where he served as the Engineer and eventually became the Manager.

In 1863, McGregor & Co. constructed a strong timber pier at Spring Garden in Wanchai. It extended 250 feet into the harbor and had a depth of 26 feet at low water. Unlike previous piers made of bamboo, this pier was built with durable timber.

Silas Enoch Burrows was an American merchant. He founded a shipping business in New York, San Francisco, and Hong Kong, and was known for his charitable acts, particularly in aiding shipwrecked mariners, including those from Sir John Franklin’s Arctic expedition.

Lawrence Mallory, an American timber merchant, lived in Hong Kong for 42 years. He was a former lieutenant in the US Navy. The area was used for timber and boat building, and later for warehouses, timber/coal storage, and other small industries.

Augustine Heard was an American merchant who co-founded Augustine and Co., a tea and opium trading company in Canton. The company became the third-largest American firm in China in the mid-19th century, and also introduced steamships to China.

Richard James Gilman, a tea-taster at Dent's in Canton, co-founded Gilman & Bowman in 1840. Actively engaged in the import-export trade and shipping, the firm achieved renown after the tea race of 1866 and played a role in establishing the HSBC in 1864.

Richard James Gilman, a tea-taster at Dent's in Canton, co-founded Gilman & Bowman in 1840. Actively engaged in the import-export trade and shipping, the firm achieved renown after the tea race of 1866 and played a role in establishing the HSBC in 1864.

Alexander Calder was an American merchant who started in Macau in 1843, where his firm traded opium and China sycee silver. He was a partner at Hughesdon, Calder & Co., and served as a director of the Marine Investment Company and Danish consul in Shanghai around 1851.

James Johnstone Keswick, a Scottish businessman, served as the taipan of Jardine Matheson & Co. He co-founded Hongkong Land with Sir Paul Chater. Keswick held key roles in Hong Kong's Legislative Council, Executive Council, and various organizations.

Charles Edward Anton was a Scottish businessman. He was the 16th tai-pan of the Jardine, Matheson & Co. and a member of the Hong Kong General Chamber of Commerce and the Legislative Council of Hong Kong.

Francis Bulkeley Johnson was a British businessman. He was a partner of the Jardine, Matheson & Co. and member of the Legislative Council of Hong Kong. He proposed the Tramways Ordinance in 1881, leading to the construction and operation of the Hongkong Tramways in 1904.

William Jardine Gresson was a British merchant and politician in Hong Kong and China. He was a managing partner in the Jardine Matheson & Co.. He also served as a Shanghai Municipal Councillor, unofficial member of the Legislative Council of Hong Kong and Executive Council of Hong Kong.

William Jardine, a Scottish physician turned opium merchant, co-founded the Hong Kong conglomerate Jardine, Matheson & Co. He played a key role in expanding trade with China, supporting the opium trade, and contributing to the First Opium War, resulting in the Treaty of Nanking in 1843.

William Jardine, a Scottish physician turned opium merchant, co-founded the Hong Kong conglomerate Jardine, Matheson & Co. He played a key role in expanding trade with China, supporting the opium trade, and contributing to the First Opium War, resulting in the Treaty of Nanking in 1843.

William Jardine, a Scottish physician turned opium merchant, co-founded the Hong Kong conglomerate Jardine, Matheson & Co. He played a key role in expanding trade with China, supporting the opium trade, and contributing to the First Opium War, resulting in the Treaty of Nanking in 1843.

David Landale was a British businessman. He was the 13th Tai-pan of the Jardine Matheson & Co. and member of the Executive Council and Legislative Council of Hong Kong. He was also a director of HSBC.

Sir James Matheson, a Scottish businessman, co-founded Jardine Matheson & Co. after after meeting William Jardine in Bombay in 1820. He played a key role in expanding trade with China, supporting the opium trade, and contributing to the First Opium War, resulting in the Treaty of Nanking in 1843.

John Johnstone Paterson served as the managing director of the firm in the 1930s and also chaired HSBC three times between 1932 and 1941. Paterson served on various committees and led the Hong Kong Volunteer Defence Corps' Special Guard Company during the Battle of Hong Kong in World War II.

Alexander Perceval was an Irish businessman. He was a Taipan of Jardine's and an unofficial member of the Legislative Council of the colony of Hong Kong from 1860 to 1864. He was also the first chairman of the Hong Kong General Chamber of Commerce.

William Jardine, a Scottish physician turned opium merchant, co-founded the Hong Kong conglomerate Jardine, Matheson & Co. He played a key role in expanding trade with China, supporting the opium trade, and contributing to the First Opium War, resulting in the Treaty of Nanking in 1843.

Edward Isaac Ezra was a prominent Jewish businessman born in Shanghai and the first native-born member of the Shanghai Municipal Council. Amassing wealth through opium trade, real estate, and investments, he served as the managing director of Shanghai Hotels Ltd. and chairman of the Far Eastern Insurance Company.

Lee Hysan was a Hong Kong businessman who was involved in the opium trade and refinery, as well as land development during the early 1900s. He bought the Jardine's Hill property, west of Causeway Bay, from Jardines for HK$3.8 million, which was later developed into Lee Garden. He was assassinated in 1928 on a street in the Central district.

William Forbes was an American businessman. He was the head partner of the Russell & Co. and was the 11th chairman of the board of Directors of HSBC from 1879 to 1880. He was the uncle of United States President Franklin Delano Roosevelt.

John Burd, a Scottish sea captain, co-founded John Burd and Co., a merchant and mariner company around 1839. They initially established the company in Canton and later moved it to Hong Kong in 1842. He was appointed as the inaugural Danish consul in Hong Kong in 1845.
The area was once home to piers and dockyards.
The area was once home to piers and dockyards.
The area was once home to piers and dockyards.
Named after the neighbouring typhoon shelter of Causeway Bay.
Named after the neighbouring typhoon shelter of Causeway Bay.
Named after the neighbouring typhoon shelter of Causeway Bay.

Named after the former site of the Hong Kong Yacht Club. The club, originally known as the Victoria Regatta, hosted its first race in 1849 and later changed its name to the Royal Hong Kong Yacht Club. The clubhouse was relocated to Kellett Island in 1938.
Dutch Lane is a path above Bowen Road and below Peak Road in Hong Kong. It was used by Dutch people to travel from their homes to their office at Royal Interocean Lines, a Dutch shipping line.

Named after Java, an Indonesian island. The street was named in reference to the headquarters of Royal Interocean Lines, a Dutch shipping company located nearby, due to their association with the Indonesian island of Java during the Dutch colonial era.

Company: Peninsular and Oriental Steam Navigation Company
Description: Named after the Chinese name of Peninsular and Oriental Steam Navigation Company.

Named after Pao Yue-Kong's World Wide Shipping, the company rapidly ascended to become the world's largest shipping company within 20 years of acquiring its initial used ship in 1955, boasting an impressive fleet with over 20 million tonnes of deadweight (DWT).
Named after the nearby Kwai Chung Container Terminals.
Named after the nearby Kwai Chung Container Terminals.
The area around Anchor Street used to be a harbour where ships would anchor. It was also close to Cosmopolitan Dockyard.

Capt George Underhill Sands was an American engineer and shipbuilder. He was the captain of a steamship in China and later bought a Shipyard in Sai Wan in Hong Kong. He served as the superintendent for HongKong, Canton & Macao Steam-Boat Co..
The shipyard was named after its founder, Irish businessman William Seybour Bailey, who established it in 1897. Operating until 1949, the shipyard was eventually dismantled.

George Fenwick was a British enginner and was the owner of shipyard located at Queen’s Road East and Ship Street in Wanchai. By 1884, Fenwick established Fenwick & Co, where he served as the Engineer and eventually became the Manager.
Named after the nearby Whampoa Dockyard.
Robert Cooke was a British engineer. He worked at Sand's Slip and Cosmopolitan Dockyard before becoming known for managing Whampoa's Kowloon Dockyard from 1880.

Robert Morton Dyer was a British businessman. Born in Japan, he was educated in Scotland and worked as a Naval Architect in Glasgow. He moved to Hong Kong and he became the Chief Manager of the Whampoa Dock Company.
David Gilles was a Scottish businessman. He was the chief manager of the Hongkong and Whampoa Dock Co.. He served as the President of the Institute of Engineers and Shipbuilders of Hong Kong.
David Gilles was a Scottish businessman. He was the chief manager of the Hongkong and Whampoa Dock Co.. He served as the President of the Institute of Engineers and Shipbuilders of Hong Kong.

Douglas Lapraik was a Scottish watchmaker, shipbuilder, and merchant. He founded Hong Kong, Canton and Macao Steamboat Company and co-founded Hong Kong and Whampoa Dock Company. He was appointed as a member of the provisional founders committee of HSBC.

Douglas Lapraik was a Scottish watchmaker, shipbuilder, and merchant. He founded Hong Kong, Canton and Macao Steamboat Company and co-founded Hong Kong and Whampoa Dock Company. He was appointed as a member of the provisional founders committee of HSBC.
Named after the neighbouring Hong Kong and Whampoa Dock, founded in 1863. It merged with Taikoo Dockyard in 1973 to form Hong Kong United Dockyard Limited, which was later relocated to Tsing Yi.
Named after the nearby Taikoo Dockyard, established in 1907. It later merged with Whampoa Dockyard to form Hong Kong United Dockyard and relocated to Tsing Yi.
Named after the nearby Taikoo Dockyard, established in 1907. It later merged with Whampoa Dockyard to form Hong Kong United Dockyard and relocated to Tsing Yi.

Westlands Road is located within the former Swire Sugar Factory boundaries and was named after the west gate of the Taikoo Dockyard, which was the main access for employees. In 1960, it was renamed Westlands Road.

John Finnie, a Scottish engineer, was a manager of Taikoo Dockyard and Engineering Company in 1937. During World War II, Finnie was interned at Stanley. After the war, he played a crucial role in rebuilding and modernizing the dockyard.
Named after the nearby Taikoo Dockyard, established in 1907. It later merged with Whampoa Dockyard to form Hong Kong United Dockyard and relocated to Tsing Yi.
Kenneth Edward Greig was the third general manager of Taikoo Dockyard.
Kenneth Edward Greig was the third general manager of Taikoo Dockyard.
Ferdinand Korn was a German chemist who became Taikoo Sugar Refinery's first manager.

Kam Li Yuen, a Chinese businessman, ran a transfer house during the Gold Rush, employing over 400 people. In 1894, he acquired a significant portion of newly reclaimed land in Central and developed it with residential and commercial buildings.

Kam Li Yuen, a Chinese businessman, ran a transfer house during the Gold Rush, employing over 400 people. In 1894, he acquired a significant portion of newly reclaimed land in Central and developed it with residential and commercial buildings.

Li Sing, a wealthy Hong Kong merchant, co-founded Wo Hing Hong, a company specializing in import and export trade with the United States. His estates were valued at three times the annual revenue of the colonial government upon his death. He also founded Tung Wah Hospital and Po Leung Kuk.

Li Sing, a wealthy Hong Kong merchant, co-founded Wo Hing Hong, a company specializing in import and export trade with the United States. His estates were valued at three times the annual revenue of the colonial government upon his death. He also founded Tung Wah Hospital and Po Leung Kuk.

Sir Catchick Paul Chater was a prominent British-Indian businessman of Armenian descent in colonial Hong Kong. Chater established Kowloon Wharf and Godown, and helped establish Dairy Farm and Hongkong Land. His philanthropy included substantial donations to the University of Hong Kong.

Sir Catchick Paul Chater was a prominent British-Indian businessman of Armenian descent in colonial Hong Kong. Chater established Kowloon Wharf and Godown, and helped establish Dairy Farm and Hongkong Land. His philanthropy included substantial donations to the University of Hong Kong.

Formerly known as North Point Wharves, the site was established in 1949 and later sold to Hutchison Whampoa in the late 1970s. The wharves were demolished in the 1980s and transformed into a residential building.
Formerly known as "Stone Godown Lane" and was renamed in 1967.
